ABSTRACT

The study of macrolactones in recent years as monomers in polymerizat ion processes has been of great interest in several research. Globalide is a macrolactone that can produce biodegradable, bioabsorbable and biocompatible polyesters that are suitable in biomedical device and biodegradable packaging applications. Traditiona lly, polymerization processes use organic solvents and metallic/chemical catalysts that can leave toxic residues in the final polymer. To obtain polymers free of organic solvents, the use of pressurized fluids such as CO 2 and propane as green solvents has been investigated. In this context, knowing the phase behavior of these systems is essential to understand the proper conditions of the polymerization process, ensuring that the reaction occurs in single -phase conditions. The work is divided into two secti ons, initially, we report the study of the phase equilibrium of the Gl + propane system at temperatures of 313.15, 323.15, 333.15 and 343.15 K, and mass fractions of propane between 0 .1 and 0.9001. All observed phase transitions occur at pressures below 2 5 bar, indicating that propane is a solvent that requires less energy expenditure than systems with CO 2, being an economic advantage in the polymerization process. The Peng -Robinson equation of state with a constant binary interaction parameter provided a good fit to the experimental data. The second stage consisted of ring -opening enzymatic polymerizations at a temperature of 338.15 K, under conditions of mass ratio (propane:globalide) of 1:2, 1:1 and 2:1, pressure conditions of 30, 70 and 110 bar and with 5% of enzyme in relation to the mass of the globalid e. The results showed conversions of up to 93%, with ğ‘€ğ‘› up to 33,804 ğ·ğ‘ and ğ‘€ğ‘¤ up to 58,864 ğ·ğ‘, with average molecular weight values greater than those reported with pressurized CO 2.
